macro_markets.query: What are the most important macroeconomic and stock market news and developments from the past 24 hours? Include major index movements, Fed/central bank news, and significant company earnings or announcements.

items.title: S&P 500 and Dow Jones Set New Record Highs as Markets Rally
items.summary: U.S. equities surged with major indexes gaining 1.6%-2.3% for the week, with the S&P 500 closing at 6,966.28 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 49,504.07, both setting new all-time highs following positive macroeconomic data.

items.title: December Jobs Report Shows Cooling Labor Market, Impacts Fed Rate Cut Expectations
items.summary: December payrolls increased by 50,000, below forecasts and following downward revisions, while the unemployment rate edged down to 4.4%, leading traders to reduce expectations for a near-term Fed rate cut to just 5% probability at the January meeting.

items.title: Materials and Industrials Lead Sector Performance
items.summary: Ten of eleven sectors posted gains for the week, with Materials surging over 4% and Industrials, Energy, and Consumer Staples each advancing around 2% or more, while Utilities finished in negative territory.

items.title: Trump Announces $200 Billion Mortgage Bond Purchase Plan
items.summary: President Donald Trump called for the purchase of $200 billion in mortgage bonds to lower mortgage rates, boosting homebuilders and housing-related companies in trading following the announcement.

items.title: Oklo Surges on Meta Nuclear Energy Deal
items.summary: Oklo jumped 12.3% after announcing a deal with Meta Platforms to secure nuclear fuel and advance its project to build a facility in Pike County, Ohio.

items.title: Fed Rate Cuts Expected Twice in 2026 Despite Near-Term Pause
items.summary: While traders have reduced expectations for a rate cut at the Fed's January meeting, they still largely expect at least two rate cuts throughout 2026, though inflation remains above the Fed's 2% target.

crypto_news.query: What are the most significant cryptocurrency and blockchain news from the past 24 hours? Include major price movements, regulatory news, and notable project developments.

items.title: Bitcoin jumps over $2,000 in minutes after U.S. tariff ruling delay and macro jitters
items.summary: Bitcoin spiked roughly $2,100 within 45 minutes after the U.S. Supreme Court delayed a key tariff legality ruling, with markets also reacting to stronger-than-expected U.S. employment data and shifting rate-cut expectations.

items.title: Tether mints $1 billion USDT amid heightened volatility and liquidity demand
items.summary: Tether minted $1 billion in new USDT as on-chain data showed high stablecoin transaction volumes and falling Tether reserves, suggesting rising demand for liquidity while traders remain cautious due to delayed tariff decisions and weaker odds of near-term rate cuts.

items.title: Bitcoin and Ethereum prices flatten as U.S. crypto ETFs see over $1.6 billion in weekly outflows
items.summary: After a strong start to the year with more than $1.5 billion of inflows, U.S. Bitcoin and Ethereum ETFs saw about $1.3 billion and $351 million in redemptions respectively this week, leaving BTC near $90,623 and ETH around $3,093 and erasing most early-2026 gains.

items.title: Fundstrat’s Tom Lee predicts new Bitcoin all‑time high above $126,000 by end of January
items.summary: Fundstrat co‑founder Tom Lee reiterated a bold forecast that Bitcoin could rally roughly 35% from early‑January levels to surpass its prior $126,000 all‑time high before month‑end, citing ETF inflows, reduced leverage after the October washout, and expected Fed rate cuts as key catalysts.

items.title: a16z crypto outlines 2026 blockchain roadmap focused on privacy and security
items.summary: Venture firm a16z crypto released a 2026 outlook arguing that future blockchain development will prioritize privacy-preserving chains, decentralized communication, and "spec is law" security models, positioning privacy and robust infrastructure as core competitive advantages for new projects.

ai_news.query: What are the most important artificial intelligence and machine learning news and developments from the past 24 hours? Include new model releases, company announcements, research breakthroughs, and industry trends.

items.title: AI Memorization Confirmed as Intrinsic Feature, Not Bug
items.summary: Research from 2024-2026 reveals that memorization in large language models is a fundamental characteristic rather than a rare flaw. Models function as lossy compression systems that can reconstruct training data when queried, with adversaries able to extract gigabytes of data from both open-source and closed models for minimal cost.

items.title: Think Academy Launches Class+ AI-Powered Intelligent Learning System at CES 2026
items.summary: Think Academy unveiled Class+, an AI-powered smart classroom system featuring real-time grading, personalized learning experiences, and advanced optical character recognition for handwritten responses. The platform generated significant interest from educators and industry professionals at CES 2026.

items.title: Higher Education Institutions Redesign Programs to Integrate AI
items.summary: Universities are fundamentally rethinking teaching goals and course design in response to AI capabilities. Professors are using AI outputs intentionally in classrooms to develop critical thinking skills, with some institutions like Mount Union offering faculty opportunities to redesign entire programs around AI integration.

gaming.query: What are the most notable video game and gaming industry news from the past 24 hours? Include game releases, announcements, esports, and industry developments.

tech_news.query: What are the most important technology news and developments from the past 24 hours? Include major product launches, company news, and significant tech industry developments. Exclude AI-specific news.

items.title: CES 2026 Showcases Crease‑less Foldable Displays and New Communication‑Focused Smartphones
items.summary: At CES 2026 in Las Vegas, Samsung demonstrated a new crease‑less foldable OLED panel, rumored to be targeted for future foldable phones, alongside niche devices like the Clicks Communicator, an Android phone designed primarily for focused communication rather than media consumption.

items.title: CES 2026 Highlights: Creaseless Foldables, RGB LED TVs, and Mainstream Smart Glasses
items.summary: Coverage of CES 2026 points to several big hardware trends for the year, including creaseless foldable devices, new RGB LED TV technologies, and a wave of smart glasses—from gaming‑oriented Asus ROG Xreal R1 AR to RayNeo’s Project eSIM that teases truly phoneless smart glasses—suggesting smart eyewear may reach the mass market.

items.title: Intel Unveils Panther Lake ‘Core Ultra Series 3’ Mobile Processors at CES 2026
items.summary: Intel introduced its Panther Lake Core Ultra Series 3 mobile CPUs, emphasizing improved performance, better power efficiency for longer laptop battery life, and stronger integrated Arc B390 graphics, with major OEMs including Dell, Asus, Acer, and Lenovo announcing laptops based on the new chips.

items.title: Slow Adoption of iOS 26 Highlights User Pushback on Liquid Glass Redesign
items.summary: Third‑party analytics indicate iOS 26 is seeing unusually slow adoption months after release, with reports suggesting that Apple’s controversial ‘Liquid Glass’ interface redesign and related usability concerns are deterring many iPhone users from upgrading.

items.title: Apple Card Program to Transition from Goldman Sachs to Chase
items.summary: Apple confirmed that its Apple Card credit card partnership will move from Goldman Sachs to JPMorgan Chase, marking a significant shift in the financial underpinnings of Apple’s consumer credit product after years of collaboration with Goldman.
